justification: The article notes that "The survey included eight scales measuring groupthink: Highly Cohesive, Promotional Leadership, Conformity…" indicating a specific Highly Cohesive scale was used to operationalize that construct.
In describing the Baptist instrument the text lists "Promotional Leadership (11 items)" among the scales, showing this construct was assessed with its own Promotional Leadership scale.
The survey "included eight scales… Conformity" and later tables present "Conformity Survey Data," demonstrating that Conformity was measured by a dedicated Conformity scale.
The list of groupthink predictors contains "Concurrence Seeking (13 items)," and subsequent tables give "Concurrence Seeking Survey Data," confirming a Concurrence Seeking scale was used.
The instrument is said to include "Anxiety (12 items)," and Table 4 is titled "Anxiety Survey Data," indicating an Anxiety scale operationalized this construct.
The measures list "Collective Efficacy (12 items)" and Table 5 presents "Collective Efficacy Survey Data," showing that a Collective Efficacy scale assessed this construct.
Although later excluded from the school study, the article reports that Baptist’s original instrument contained "Hidden Profiles (9 items)," implying a Hidden Profiles scale measured that construct.
The predictors list "Trust (10 items)," and Table 6 shows "Trust Survey Data," demonstrating a Trust scale was used to measure the Trust construct.
